I see this all the time whenever I'm passing through redneck Appalachia or going camping there, and I just don't get it. Just C4s, C3s, classic Camaros and Mustangs, Mopar, various cool 40s and 50s cars, etc, just parked and abandoned in a field.

These cars must have been bought brand new or slightly used, for good money probably. If they're broken then why not spend the money on basic repairs if they could clearly afford the car in the first place? Or if they were unrepairable, why not scrap them? Besides they don't look "broken" they look like someone just parked them in pristine condition next to the driveway and just never came back. I mean these are some people's dream cars or collector's pieces that could have been potentially worth shitloads of money if they had just been given the bare minimum of care like just putting a car cover over them. What causes people to just abandon their cars like this, on their own property no less?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Ford almost didn't survive the 1940s. The newly redesigned 1941 models were facelifted for '42, replacing the electric shaver grille with thick horizontal bars before the US entry into WWII halted production. Company president Edsel Ford died of cancer on May 26, 1943, not yet 50 years old. With his passing, the doddering Henry Ford, nearly 80 years old, announced that he would resume direct control of the company but his wife and daughter-in-law demanded that he instead turn the reigns over to his grandson, then serving in the Navy. They owned a large amount of the company's stocks and threatened to sell them if he didn't comply. Henry was furious but licked. He consented and Henry Ford II returned home to take control.

By this point Ford's financial situation was increasingly precarious and the FDR Administration contemplated nationalizing the company if need be to keep wartime production going. Henry had a distrust of accounting departments and never bothered creating one so nobody knew exactly how much money Ford was taking in and spending. After V-J Day, civilian production was slow to resume and major labor strikes, raw materials shortages, and inflation struck the United States for the next two years.

KWh prices vary greatly by region, type of account (residential vs commercial etc.) And even time of day (peak pricing.) According to the BLS average US price was $0.166 per kWh in October https://www.bls.gov/regions/midwest/data/AverageEnergyPrices_SelectedAreas_Table.htm
Elon's tweet said 1.7kWh/mi as you said, so fuel cost/mi is $0.282, pretty close to the 0.25 you threw out (likely a different assumption on the kWh price.)
Diesel also varies in price as de allí know, and fuel economy can change depending on truck, load, route, etc. 8 mpg is a decent estimate of real world good conditions (and we all know Elon's figure isn't for an overweight oversize thru the Rockies) and diesel was a bit over $5/gallon, call ir $5.50. That vives us fuel cost of $0.69/ mile, so yes on paper at today's pricing a Tesla semi saves quite a bit of money on fuel.

So long as you don't need to haul more than 500 miles in a day (or 450 miles next year, 350 miles a few years from now...) and your destinations will all have adequate chargers around (fat chance) then this thing could be an attractive proposition.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26130992
The whole point of F1's trick front suspension was so that it would be possible to mount a stiff spring rate and damper while having the road shock insulated by longitudinal movement of the wheels. To achieve that the wishbones were attached to a subframe which were mounted to the central chassis using rubber-nylon composite bushings.

In theory it was supposed to be the best of both worlds: A comfortable ride, but still giving the driver precise control. In practice, though, it was a wash because McLaren in the end utilized a soft suspension anyway likely because using a stiff suspension with just the bushings alone was still too harsh a ride or they just weren't lasting long enough or perhaps a combination of both. In any case, when it came time to build the racecar, the rubber bushings would be replaced with ones made of aluminium.

When put to the handling tests, the F1 was trailing far behind the supercars of the day due to the soft suspension set-up. They went to patent the technology, but at the end of the day, it simply didn't work all that well.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26136804
vr38 has a huge magnesium oil pan with an axle pass through to the front diff
coincidentally the oil pump is also located in the huge pan.

If you were going to put the vr38 into a z, you won't have proper ground clearance anymore if you left it as is.
Otherwise you would have to come up with a dry sump setup and have to come up with a new front cover (existing one is now too long)

Not to mention the bellhousing normally bolts to the pan so now half of your transmission bolts attach to nothing and your flywheel is exposed to air.

the trigger wheel for the vr38 is located on the flex plate so you'd need a 1 off custom part

Plus the FS6R31A is the wrong bellhousing bolt pattern for the VR38

last_replies.com:
>overheating

>no heat

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26137663
Learn what systems are in the vehicle, what they do, and why. Problems are just things not working how they're supposed to, and the symptom usually informs the cause because logic. Sometimes things are more complicated, and sometimes the car's sensors and computer figure it out for you and it spits out a trouble code you can reference that tells you what's going on.

>>26137682
This. The same coolant is used for both cooling the engine and heating the cabin. Low coolant volume results in both poor circulation/pumping as well as a reduced thermal mass for absorbing heat off the engine and releasing it at the heater core and main radiator.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Few examples of "an answer to a question nobody asked" are worse than the Dodge La Femme, a female-oriented trim package for the 1955 Royal Lancer hardtop coupe. Based on the La Comtesse concept car, it had pink and silver interior trim and a medallion big enough to contain an owner-chosen monogram. Each car also came with a cosmetics bag containing a complete set of makeup and a cigarette lighter and case. The cosmetics were supplied by Chicago-based Evans Co., and guards were posted around the Dodge assembly line to keep workers from stealing the high value cosmetics. A compartment on the back of the driver’s seat held a complete rain wear ensemble, including a vinyl raincoat, bonnet, and umbrella.

The La Femme returned in '56 now with a gold trimmed theme, no cosmetics kit, and only the rain kit. A higher power D-500 engine was standard. It did not come back for 1957 and as Chrysler did not separate production from the rest of the Royal Lancer, the number of La Femmes produced is unknown, but certainly not more than a few hundred. All in all, the La Femme was a poor idea and a product of 1950s marketing mentalities that would nowadays come off as laughably primitive.

Yeah, it happens. The adhesive sealer dried out over time and the lens falls off.
